chapter.title: LD are hidden disabilities
chapter.content:
LD are hidden disabilities

One of the key attributes of LD is that they are hidden disabilities. This makes them difficult to understand and accept, both for the individual with the disability and for friends, family, acquaintances and co-workers. This lack of understanding and acceptance can hinder self-determination.

Compare this with physical disabilities that are often easily seen and understood. Consider for a moment, what sorts of disabilities are more visible than LD?

After you have thought about your answer, click the forward arrow for some examples.

chapter.title: Examples of visible disabilities
chapter.content:
Examples of visible disabilities

Examples of more visible disabilities include:

  • various types of physical disabilities;
  • visual impairments; and
  • hearing impairments.

What obvious accommodations may be used by individuals with these “more visible” disabilities?

chapter.title: Examples of accommodations for visible disabilities
chapter.content:
Examples of accommodations for visible disabilities

Examples of obvious accommodations that may be used by individuals with these “more visible” disabilities include:

  • curb cuts and ramps;
  • braille materials or screen readers;
  • closed captioning broadcasts;
  • sign language interpreters; and
  • special grips or handles.

chapter.title: Expectations of individuals with visible differences
chapter.content:
Expectations of individuals with visible differences

Because of the visibility of their impairments, we know not to expect an individual in a wheelchair to climb stairs, or an individual who is blind to read a standard textbook, or an individual with hearing impairments to listen without some type of accommodation such as a hearing aid or interpreter.

However, many disabilities are invisible and can include debilitating pain, fatigue, dizziness, cognitive dysfunctions, brain injuries, learning differences and mental health disorders, as well as hearing and vision impairments. Invisible disabilities are not always obvious, but can limit activities.

Let’s examine some of the indicators of one category of invisible disabilities, learning disabilities.

chapter.title: Areas of functioning possibly affected by LD
chapter.content:
Areas of functioning possibly affected by LD

Learning disabilities affect less visible areas of functioning than other disabilities. What makes understanding LD more complicated is that difficulties in these areas of functioning are not always caused by LD.

Some areas of functioning possibly affected by LD are:

  • listening comprehension;
  • written expression;
  • basic reading skill;
  • mathematics problem solving;
  • memory;
  • communication;
  • calculation; and
  • social competence.

chapter.title: Identify reasons other than LD that might explain poor performance
chapter.content:
Identify reasons other than LD that might explain poor performance

Consider this list of areas of functioning that could be affected by LD. What reasons other than having a learning disability might explain poor performance in one or more of these areas?

After you have thought about your answer, click the forward arrow for some additional explanations of poor performance.

chapter.title: Other explanations for poor performance
chapter.content:
Other explanations for poor performance

While many answers may apply, other explanations of poor performance might include:

  • emotional, physical or mental health issues;
  • stress or outside pressures; and
  • undiagnosed visual or hearing impairments.

In addition, individuals with LD and/or the persons who work with those individuals may also attribute poor performance to:

  • lack of intelligence;
  • lack of initiative or motivation;
  • laziness or carelessness, or
  • lack of family support.

chapter.title: Individuals with LD often blame themselves for poor performance
chapter.content:
Individuals with LD often blame themselves for poor performance

Often the individual with a learning disability blames him- or herself for the lack of performance without understanding that it is based on a specific learning disability. It is easy for individuals with LD to feel that they are not very “smart,” which means that rather than understanding their LD, they have an overall feeling of incompetence.

Now that we have considered this major challenge for individuals with LD, let’s take a closer look at self-determination through our first guiding question.
